caseStudies.title: Unlocking Creativity and Supporting Neurodivergent Actors
caseStudies.description: In the entertainment industry, where authenticity drives compelling narratives, supporting neurodivergent actors is vital for unlocking diverse creativity and representation.
caseStudies.subtitle: Patience (Channel 4 / Eagle Eye Drama, January 2025)
caseStudies.body:
In the entertainment industry, where authenticity drives compelling narratives, supporting neurodivergent actors is vital for unlocking diverse creativity and representation. Our team of Clinical Psychologists are well versed in supporting actors with neurodivergence (including ADHD, Autism, Dyslexia, Dyspraxia, Dyscalculia and Tourette's), as well as reviewing scripts for accurate presentation and representation, and considering the individual needs of cast and crew.

Channel 4's 2025 crime drama Patience, serves as a great case example, starring autistic and ADHD actor Ella Maisy Purvis as the neurodivergent archivist Patience Evans, who aids detectives in solving cases with her unique pattern-spotting skills. Purvis's authentic portrayal, informed by her own experiences, delivers nuanced performances that challenge stereotypes and foster empathy, much like how Robin Williams channelled his ADHD into iconic roles or Bella Ramsey infused vulnerability into The Last of Us.

By casting neurodivergent talent in these roles, productions such as Patience not only enrich storytelling but also demonstrate how hyperfocus and empathy, often traits of neurodiversity, elevate improvisation and emotional depth, proving that diverse minds are essential for innovative, relatable content. Neurodiversity isn't a deficit; it's a difference in how brains process the world, encompassing ADHD, autism, dyslexia, OCD, dyspraxia, and Tourette's. For actors, this can mean hyperfocus on character details that others overlook or an innate empathy that makes emotional scenes profoundly real. As voiceover director Marnie Demchick notes, "Neurodivergent performers bring really nuanced performances, and often bring something to a role that other people don't".

The entertainment industry mirrors society: diverse, messy, and full of potential. By supporting neurodivergent actors, we unlock creativity that benefits everyone, from more empathetic stories to a workforce that's truly representative. Despite breakthroughs like Patience, neurodivergent actors face significant barriers, including sensory sensitivities during auditions, last-minute script changes risking burnout, and the exhaustion of social masking to appear "neurotypical". To build on successes like Patience, which benefited from collaborative writing with Purvis to ensure fidelity, the industry should consider practical supports, such as risk reviewing a script, identifying strengths and potential challenging traits that may require additional support, time to allow for processing and integration, sensory breaks, clear communication, advocates for neurodiversity, and flexible schedules. As advocates and allies, we can amplify these voices through inclusive casting and resources like Equity's autistic artist networks, and creating inclusive scripts to attract neurodivergent talent, and where neurodivergence can thrive.

caseStudies.title: Behind Every Shot is a Story of Teamwork, Tenacity and Welfare
caseStudies.description: In the world of unscripted challenge TV, every day brings a new location, a fresh challenge, and a different problem to solve.
Devastating consequences of sensationalism, intrusion, and online harassment endured by those in the public eye, as well as the psychological and familial wreckage left behind.
caseStudies.title: Caroline Flack: Search for the Truth
caseStudies.body:
Caroline Flack: Search for the truth (streaming on Disney Plus 10th November 2025) highlights the devastating consequences of sensationalism, intrusion, and online harassment endured by those in the public eye, as well as the psychological and familial wreckage left behind.

The documentary highlights more than ever, that responsible and ethical reporting, across news media, TV production, and social media, is not just about journalistic standards; it is about protecting real lives from irreversible harm. When I am tasked with delivering mental health awareness training to production teams, I very much cite the often mis-attributed Hippocratic oath, “Primum non nocere", first, do no harm, to promote the importance of ethical production and storytelling, and minimising risk to those we expose on screen.

Caroline Flack’s final months were marked by intense media scrutiny and social media vitriol following her arrest, which compounded her existing emotional vulnerabilities and led to an overwhelming sense of isolation and despair. Her family recounts how destructive public shaming, relentless press coverage, and legal pressures worked together to rob her of hope, deeply affecting not only Caroline but also her closest relatives and friends. Panic attacks, self-harm, and a preoccupation with negative commentary were recurrent in her communications—reflections of a person who needed protection and kindness from the media and public, but instead received both suspicion and cruelty. Caroline Flack: Search for the Truth exposes not only the misrepresentation and systemic failures within policing and justice, but also the darker side of public discourse and social media commentary — a climate where personal suffering becomes fodder for clicks and outrage rather than compassion and understanding. Caroline’s mother, Christine, conducts her own investigation, assembling evidence of institutional and societal shortcomings, and advocating for change and justice—an effort motivated by grief but also by a desire to restore dignity to her daughter’s memory. Her story calls for greater accountability among journalists, producers, and social media companies. Sensational headlines, intrusive reporting, and the viral spread of negativity on digital platforms have real psychological effects. When unchecked, they can intensify distress and directly contribute to tragedies like Caroline Flack’s. Ultimately, the coverage and reflection on Caroline Flack’s story underscore the need for a cultural shift, to value kindness over sensationalism, and empathy over judgement. “Be kind” is more than a plea; it’s a moral imperative in an age where words and stories travel instantly, and the impact on individuals and families can be profound and permanent. Following the lessons of Caroline Flack’s life and legacy, media professionals, producers, content creators, and the public alike must remember that behind each story is a human being whose wellbeing should be considered against public curiosity or commercial gain.

Let “Be kind” be the guiding principle for anyone with the power to influence, discuss, or disseminate stories—because genuine compassion can save lives, while carelessness can destroy them.

Well done to the team at Curious Films, Dov Freedman, Sophie Clayton-Payne, and the powerful voices of Chris and the Flack Family, Mollie Grosberg , Louisa McDonald, and Paul Morris. Proud to have supported this timely documentary, and hope that this further adds to Caroline’s legacy.

caseStudies.title: Duty of Care: Supporting the Next Generation of Stars
caseStudies.body:
Simon Cowell: The Next Act is an intimate Netflix docuseries that follows the legendary music
mogul as he embarks on his next venture to create a brand-new boy band for a new generation. For the cast, the series tracks the journey from open casting calls through intensive training, and launching the group’s debut single, showing both the competitive nature of selection, and Cowell’s personal and professional stakes in proving he can still discover the next global pop sensation.

The process of forming a boy band has always captured public imagination, from televised
auditions in the 1990s and early 2000s to today’s social media-driven talent searches. Yet, the landscape surrounding these journeys has changed dramatically. Young hopefuls no longer face scrutiny from just weekly broadcast audiences but from a 24/7 digital world where every moment and move can be replayed, dissected, and shared, as well as the expectations to compete and be compared to renowned boy bands from previous generations, raising the stakes and stress even higher.

 This evolution demands a renewed and deeper sense of Duty of Care. Teenagers and young adults
entering such highly competitive environments are often still developing emotionally and socially. Exposure to intense competition, future online commentary, and sudden fame can heighten risks of anxiety, low self-esteem, and distorted identity formation. In earlier decades, the pressures were real but more contained; now, visibility and vulnerability are amplified by the constant presence of cameras and global online communities.

 Being directed by an iconic industry figure such as Simon Cowell means every action and
performance will be compared to legendary boy bands from previous generations. This can foster unrealistic pressure and fear of not living up to these standards. TV talent programmes following suit must therefore actively manage expectations, emphasising personal growth, teamwork, and sustainability over fame. Preparing a potential cast of band contenders for the inevitable criticism and emotional scrutiny is crucial, as recent experience shows that sudden changes or tragedy can deeply affect both the process and participants’ mental health.

 A robust framework of care should surround each performer and their family, before, during, and after filming, and beyond a production where a band navigates the realities of such exposure and potential success, and the high expectations and loss of anonymity and privacy. This includes transparent communication about expectations, access to mental health professionals, and guidance on managing public exposure. Mentorship from experienced artists can ground young performers in the realities of the creative industry, while workshops on social media literacy and personal boundaries can help them navigate fame with resilience and authenticity.

 Ultimately, shaping a boy band today is not only about finding harmony in voices, but also
about building a safe, informed, and supportive environment where young artists can thrive. When Duty of Care becomes a core value rather than a compliance measure, it protects not just reputations, but the wellbeing and futures of the people behind the music and the performing talent.

 Mindzone Media are proud to have supported the cast through the lifespan of the project for Box
To Box’s six-part docuseries, Simon Cowell: The Next Act, streaming on Netflix from 10th December 2025.
